refsect1.title: DESCRIPTION
refsect1.para: This tool reports differences between two repository histories. The histories may be presented as git repository directories or as fast-import streams, or as one of each.

Revisions are compared in commit order; each is represented by a SHA1 hash of the tree content and its metadata (committer name/date, author name/date). An algorithm resembling that of diff1 is used to identify spans of identical commits and pick out changes, insertions, and deletions.

For each changed, inserted, or deleted revision, one line is normally emitted identifying it by commit ID (for a repo) or mark (for a stream file) in the first history. In change reports, the corresponding revision in the second history is similarly identified and the report indicates the nature of the changes.
A trailing statistics line summarizes the operation counts.

refsect1.title: OPTIONS
refsect1.para: The --showequal or -e option enables listing of equal commits.
The --single or -s option compares single commits in detail. The argument must be a pair of commit IDs (marks or hashes) separated by an equals sign.

The --ignore or -i option causes differences between specified parts to be ignored. Part tags are author, authordate, committer, commitdate, comment, timezone, and tree; one, or a comma-separated list, can be specified.
The --fullhash or -f option forces reporting of full 40-digit hash IDs, rather than the normal short hash.
The --verbose or -v option enables debugging messages that are probably only of interest to developers; consult the source code for details.

refsect1.title: BUGS
refsect1.para: Parent pointers are not yet compared, so on multibranched repos differences in DAG structure will not appear in the report.
The above deficiencies are likely to be fixed in a future release.

When a blob changes, it causes tree differences to be reported in all subsequent revisions containing the blob, rather than only the first commit in which it occurs. This probably will not be fixed; while it would be theoretically possible, the computational cost of the comparison would become quite high.
